Multilingual Text Code Generator.cpp

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*
00002 MULTILINGUAL TEXT CODE GENERATOR 
00003 This code generator is used to conveniently compare the english master text file with another foreign language 
00004 such as German and verify that the appropriate language file is in perfect synch with the English.  Verifying 
00005 that all of the strings have the correct order of printf format specifiers and the precise number.  If 
00006 different, the errors are recorded via comments proceeding the string in question in the new file.  For 
00007 simplicity, the German language will be used in examples throughout this documention.  The comments will be
00008 specially marked with "CONFLICT#xxx:  error message" which can be searched for.  The comment will report 
00009 the format specifiers used in the english version.
00010 
00011 ASSUMPTIONS
00012 - No functions exist in any of the master files
00013 - Users don't use single strings using:
00014             STR16 str[] = L"Single String";
00015       Instead use:
00016             STR16 str[] = 
00017             {
00018                   L"Single String";
00019             }
00020 - Users don't use comments containing the { character later followed by the L" token.  The code generator 
00021   will mistaken that for a string.
00022 - Users don't use nested braces (2D text arrays)
00023             
00024 
00025 
00026 AUTHOR:  Kris Morness
00027 CREATED:    Feb 16, 1999
00028 */
00029 
00030 #ifdef _DEBUG
00031 
00032 #include <stdio.h>
00033 #include "types.h"
00034 #include "Language Defines.h"
00035 #include "debug.h"
00036 #include "Fileman.h"
00037 
00038 //Currently in JA2's _EnglishText, these tokens make up all of the
00039 //format specifiers that are actually used.  Feel free to add more,
00040 //but make sure you change NUM_TOKENS accordingly.  These tokens assume
00041 //the previous character is a % character.
00042 UINT8 SupportedTokens[] =
00043 {
00044       'd',
00045       'c',
00046       's',
00047       'S',
00048       '%',
00049 };
00050 #define NUM_TOKENS      5
00051 
00052 enum
00053 {
00054       //look for { character followed by L" before } to upgrade to INSIDE_STRING
00055       OUTSIDE_STRING_ARRAY, 
00056 
00057       //look for } character to downgrade to OUTSIDE_STRING_ARRAY
00058       //look for L" characters to upgrade to INSIDE_STRING
00059       INSIDE_STRING_ARRAY,  
00060 
00061       //look for " character to downgrade to INSIDE_STRING_ARRAY
00062       INSIDE_STRING,
00063 };
00064 
00065 //Specifies where the master english file is located relative to the exe directory
00066 #define LCG_WORKINGDIRECTORY                    "build\\utils"
00067 #define LCG_ENGLISHMASTERFILE                   "_EnglishText.c"
00068 
00069 //The commandline argument (add different one for each language supported 
00070 //***Only one can exist at a time and it is controlled by Language Defines.h )
00071 #define LCG_COMMANDLINEARGUMENT                 "-GERMAN"
00072 #define LCG_FOREIGNMASTERFILE                   "_GermanText.c"
00073 #define LCG_FOREIGNNEWFILE                            "_NewGermanText.c"
00074 
00075 //Given a file pointer, searches for the next DB string
00076 UINT32 CountDoubleByteStringsInFile( UINT8 * filename );
00077 
00078 
00079 //One function does it all.  First looks for the cmd line arg, and if it matches
00080 //the above define, searches for the files, and processes them automatically.
00081 BOOLEAN ProcessIfMultilingualCmdLineArgDetected( UINT8 *str )
00082 {
00083       STRING512               ExecDir;
00084       STRING512               CurrDir;
00085       STRING512               Dir;
00086       UINT32 uiEnglishStrings, uiForeignStrings;
00087 
00088       //check if command line argument matches the LCG's
00089       if( strcmp( (const char *)str, LCG_COMMANDLINEARGUMENT ) )
00090       { //string is different, so return
00091             return FALSE;
00092       }
00093 
00094       //Record the exe directory
00095       GetExecutableDirectory( ExecDir );
00096       //Record the curr directory used (we will restore before leaving)
00097       GetFileManCurrentDirectory( CurrDir );
00098 
00099       //Build the working directory name
00100       sprintf( Dir, "%s\\%s", ExecDir, LCG_WORKINGDIRECTORY );
00101       
00102       //Set the working directory
00103       if( !SetFileManCurrentDirectory( Dir ) )
00104       { //We failed meaning the directory name is incorrect or non-existant
00105             AssertMsg( 0, "Failed to set directory location while attempting to activate multilingual text code generator." );
00106             return FALSE;
00107       }
00108 
00109       //verify that all files exist
00110       if( !FileExists( LCG_ENGLISHMASTERFILE ) )
00111       {
00112             AssertMsg( 0, "Failed to find master english file while attempting to activate multilingual text code generator." );
00113             return FALSE;
00114       }
00115       if( !FileExists( LCG_FOREIGNMASTERFILE ) )
00116       {
00117             AssertMsg( 0, "Failed to find master foreign file while attempting to activate multilingual text code generator." );
00118             return FALSE;
00119       }
00120 
00121       //ALL PRELIMINARY CHECKS HAVE SUCCEEDED.  
00122       //Begin file preparation checks...
00123 
00124       //STEP1:  Read the English master file and count the number of DB strings that exist
00125       uiEnglishStrings = CountDoubleByteStringsInFile( (UINT8 *)LCG_ENGLISHMASTERFILE );
00126 
00127       //STEP2:  Read the Foreigh master file and count the number of DB strings that exist
00128       uiForeignStrings = CountDoubleByteStringsInFile( (UINT8 *)LCG_FOREIGNMASTERFILE );
00129 
00130       //Make sure they match, otherwise, we can't continue.
00131       if( uiEnglishStrings != uiForeignStrings )
00132       {
00133             AssertMsg( 0, String( "Mismatch during LCG preparation:  English DB strings: %d, Foreign DB strings: %d",
00134                   uiEnglishStrings, uiForeignStrings ) );
00135             return FALSE;
00136       }
00137 
00138       //Mission complete!  Reset the previously known directory, and return TRUE;
00139       SetFileManCurrentDirectory( CurrDir );
00140       return TRUE;
00141 }
00142 
00143 UINT32 CountDoubleByteStringsInFile( UINT8 * filename )
00144 {
00145       FILE *fp = NULL;
00146       UINT32 uiNumStrings = 0;
00147 
00148       //open file
00149       fp = fopen( (const char *)filename, "r" );
00150       if( !fp )
00151       {
00152             return 0;
00153       }
00154 
00155       fclose( fp );
00156       return uiNumStrings;
00157 }
00158 
00159 #endif //_DEBUG
